title: Financial Communication
description: Explore how you talk about money and what makes those conversations work.

questions.text: When it comes to talking about money, I'm naturally...
choices: Pretty open—it doesn't stress me out
A bit guarded—it feels vulnerable
Practical—I talk about it when needed
Avoidant—I'd rather not if I can help it

therapeutic.rationale: Money conversation comfort varies widely. Open types discuss freely; guarded types feel exposed; practical types are functional; avoidant types struggle. Partners often have different comfort levels, creating communication gaps.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The open partner may push conversations the guarded partner finds overwhelming; the guarded partner may leave the open partner feeling shut out. Meet in the middle—scheduled, boundaried money talks.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort levels make money conversations easier to navigate. You understand each other's pace.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when money comes up in conversation? Where does that feeling come from?

questions.text: The money conversations I'd most want us to have regularly are about...
choices: How we're doing against our goals
Any worries or stress either of us has
Upcoming expenses or decisions
Our dreams and what we're working toward

therapeutic.rationale: Preferred money conversations reveal what matters most. Goal-trackers want progress; stress-sharers want emotional safety; planners want practical alignment; dreamers want vision. All are valuable—make room for each.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conversation priorities may leave one partner unsatisfied. The stress-sharer may feel the goal-tracker is cold; the goal-tracker may feel the stress-sharer is dwelling. Alternate between types.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conversation priority focuses your money talks. You naturally want to discuss the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What money conversation have you been wanting to have? What's stopped you from having it?

questions.text: When money conversations get tense, I tend to...
choices: Push through until we resolve it
Take a break and come back to it
Get quiet and withdraw
Try to lighten the mood or change the subject

therapeutic.rationale: Tension responses reveal conflict patterns. Push-throughers pursue resolution; break-takers regulate; withdrawers protect; mood-lighteners deflect. Mismatched styles can escalate conflict.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The push-througher may feel the withdrawer is avoiding; the withdrawer may feel the push-througher is attacking. Learn to signal when you need a break—and commit to coming back.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared tension response means you'll navigate conflict similarly. Know your shared style's blind spots.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens in your body when money conversations get tense? What do you need in those moments?

questions.text: I feel best about our financial communication when...
choices: We're both being completely honest
The conversation stays calm and respectful
We end up on the same page
I feel heard and understood

therapeutic.rationale: What makes money conversations feel good varies. Honesty-seekers want truth; calm-seekers want safety; alignment-seekers want agreement; understanding-seekers want empathy. Knowing your partner's need helps you provide it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs may mean different satisfaction criteria. The honesty-seeker may push harder than the calm-seeker can handle; the understanding-seeker may feel the alignment-seeker is just trying to win.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared criteria mean you'll both feel good about conversations for the same reasons.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes a money conversation feel successful to you? What makes it feel like a failure?

questions.text: I'd like us to talk about money...
choices: More often than we do now
Less often—we're good
About the same, but differently
When it comes up naturally

therapeutic.rationale: Frequency preferences reveal current satisfaction. More-often seekers feel under-discussed; less-often seekers feel over-discussed; differently-seekers want quality change; natural-flow types resist structure. Naming this helps you adjust.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different frequency needs require negotiation. The more-often partner may need scheduled check-ins; the less-often partner may need bounded conversations. Find your rhythm.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared frequency preference means you're aligned on how much money talk is right. Maintain your rhythm.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How often do you talk about money now? Is it enough? Too much? What would be ideal?
